title: Japanese submarine Ro-113
text:
Ro-113 was an <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Navy">Imperial Japanese Navy</a> <a href="Ro-100-class%20submarine">"Ro-100"-class</a> <a href="submarine">submarine</a>. Completed and commissioned in October 1943, she served in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, operating off the <a href="Admiralty%20Islands">Admiralty Islands</a>, in the <a href="Indian%20Ocean">Indian Ocean</a> — where she sank the last <a href="Allies%20of%20World%20War%20II">Allied</a> ship <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>ed by a Japanese submarine during World War II — and off the <a href="Philippine%20Islands">Philippine Islands</a>. She was sunk in February 1945.
Design and description.
The "Ro-100" class was a medium-sized, coastal submarine derived from the preceding <a href="Kaich%C5%AB%20type%20submarine">"Kaichū" type</a>. They <a href="Displacement%20%28ship%29">displaced</a> surfaced and submerged. The submarines were long, had a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of and a <a href="draft%20%28hull%29">draft</a> of . They had a <a href="double%20hull">double hull</a> and a diving depth of .
For surface running, the boats were powered by two <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s, each driving one <a href="propeller%20shaft">propeller shaft</a>. When submerged each propeller was driven by a <a href="electric%20motor">electric motor</a>. They could reach on the surface and underwater. On the surface, the "Ro-100"s had a range of at ; submerged, they had a range of at .
The boats were armed with four internal bow <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s and carried a total of eight <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es. They were also armed with two single mounts for <a href="Type%2096%2025%20mm%20AT/AA%20Gun">Type 96</a> <a href="anti-aircraft%20gun">anti-aircraft gun</a>s or a single <a href="8%20cm/40%203rd%20Year%20Type%20naval%20gun"></a> L/40 AA gun.
Construction and commissioning.
"Ro-113" was <a href="Keel-laying">laid down</a> as Submarine No. 404 on 11 July 1942 by <a href="Kawasaki%20Heavy%20Industries">Kawasaki</a> at <a href="Kobe">Kobe</a>, <a href="Japan">Japan</a>. Renamed Ro-113 on 5 February 1943, she was <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 24 April 1943. She was completed and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 12 October 1943.
Service history.
October 1943–May 1944.
Upon commissioning, "Ro-113" was attached to the <a href="Kure%20Naval%20District">Kure Naval District</a> and was assigned to Submarine <a href="Squadron%20%28naval%29">Squadron</a> 11 for workups. While conducting a simulated <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a> attack in the <a href="Seto%20Inland%20Sea">Seto Inland Sea</a> on 9 November 1943, she collided with the <a href="battleship">battleship</a> in the <a href="Iyo%20Nada">Iyo Nada</a>, suffering minor damage and no casualties. She proceeded to <a href="Kure%2C%20Hiroshima">Kure</a> for inspection and repairs. She resumed workups on 2 December 1943 and called at <a href="Tokuyama%2C%20Yamaguchi">Tokuyama</a> from 2 to 6 December 1943 to refuel.
On 31 January 1944, "Ro-113" was reassigned to Submarine Division 30. She departed <a href="Kure%2C%20Hiroshima">Kure</a>, Japan, on 23 February 1944 for her first combat operation, an <a href="Antisubmarine%20warfare">antisubmarine</a> patrol in the <a href="Ryukyu%20Islands">Ryukyu Islands</a> under the direction of the <a href="Grand%20Escort%20Command">Grand Escort Command</a>. She was reassigned to Submarine Division 51 in Submarine Squadron 7 in the <a href="6th%20Fleet%20%28Imperial%20Japanese%20Navy%29">6th Fleet</a> on 25 March 1944. On 21 May 1944 she departed Kure bound for <a href="Saipan">Saipan</a> in the <a href="Mariana%20Islands">Mariana Islands</a>, which she reached on 29 May 1944.
First war patrol.
On 8 June 1944, "Ro-113" departed Saipan to begin her first war patrol, ordered to join a submarine patrol line north of <a href="New%20Ireland%20%28island%29">New Ireland</a> in the <a href="Bismarck%20Archipelago">Bismarck Archipelago</a>. She received orders on 14 June 1944 to move to a new patrol area north of <a href="Guam">Guam</a>, and on 16 June 1944 she was reassigned to Patrol Unit C along with the submarines , , and . Ordered on 22 June 1944 to return to base, she arrived at <a href="Chuuk%20Lagoon">Truk</a> on 27 June 1944.
July–August 1944.
On 10 July 1944, "Ro-113" departed Truk bound for <a href="Sasebo">Sasebo</a>, Japan, which she reached on 17 July 1944. On 15 August 1944, Submarine Division 51 was disbanded, and "Ro-113" and "Ro-115" were reassigned directly to Submarine Squadron 8 in the 6th Fleet. "Ro-113" departed Kure on 7 September 1944 and headed for <a href="Penang%20Island">Penang</a> in Japanese-occupied <a href="British%20Malaya">British Malaya</a>, arriving there on 27 September 1944 for operations in the <a href="Indian%20Ocean">Indian Ocean</a>.
Second war patrol.
"Ro-113" got underway from Penang on 25 October 1944 to begin her second war patrol, assigned a patrol area in the <a href="Bay%20of%20Bengal">Bay of Bengal</a>. On 6 November 1944 she torpedoed and sank the <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a> 3,827-<a href="gross%20register%20ton">gross register ton</a> <a href="merchant%20ship">merchant ship</a> "Marion Moller" — the last <a href="Allies%20of%20World%20War%20II">Allied</a> ship torpedoed by a Japanese submarine in the Indian Ocean — in the Bay of Bengal at . The <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> <a href="destroyer">destroyer</a>s , , and arrived on the scene a few hours later and began a pursuit of "Ro-113". The British <a href="Task%20Force%2066">Task Force 66</a>, centered round the <a href="escort%20aircraft%20carrier">escort aircraft carrier</a>s and , also became involved, but "Ro-113" escaped and returned to Penang on 13 November 1944.
Third war patrol.
"Ro-113" began her third war patrol on 28 November 1944, again tasked with attacking Allied shipping in the Bay of Bengal. A <a href="Royal%20Air%20Force">Royal Air Force</a> <a href="Consolidated%20B-24%20Liberator">Liberator</a> <a href="bomber">bomber</a> attacked her in the Bay of Bengal off <a href="Madras">Madras</a>, <a href="India">India</a>, on 3 December 1944, but she survived undamaged. She reported sinking a <a href="Transport%20%28ship%29">transport</a> on 18 December 1944 and a second transport on 19 December, but postwar analysis found no evidence of her having sunk any ships on these dates. Off Penang as "Ro-113" was concluding her patrol, the Royal Navy submarine fired six torpedoes at her, all of which exploded prematurely, leading "Thule"′s commanding officer to claim the sinking of "Ro-113", but "Ro-113" survived and reached Penang safely.
Fourth war patrol.
"Ro-113" began her fourth war patrol on 20 January 1945, departing Penang, pausing briefly at <a href="Singapore">Singapore</a> later in the day, and then heading for her patrol area in the <a href="South%20China%20Sea">South China Sea</a> west of Luzon. On 4 February 1945, the 6th Fleet ordered "Ro-113" and the submarines , , and "Ro-115" to proceed to <a href="Kaohsiung">Takao</a>, <a href="Formosa">Formosa</a>, unload their reserve torpedoes and deck gun ammunition there, and then head for <a href="Batulinao">Batulinao</a> on the northern coast of Luzon to rescue <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Navy%20Air%20Service">Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service</a> pilots stranded in Luzon's <a href="Aparri">Aparri</a> area and transport them to Takao. After calling at Takao from 7 to 9 February 1945, "Ro-113" got back underway and set course for Batulinao.
Loss.
"Ro-113" was on the surface in the <a href="Luzon%20Strait">Luzon Strait</a> in the vicinity of <a href="Babuyan%20Island">Babuyan Island</a> north of Luzon in the predawn darkness of 13 February 1945 when the U.S. Navy submarine detected her on <a href="radar">radar</a> at 02:15 bearing 220 degrees from "Batfish" at a range of . "Batfish" lost contact at 02:41 at a range of when "Ro-113" submerged.
At 03:10, "Ro-113" surfaced and "Batfish"′s <a href="radar%20detector">radar detector</a> picked up her radar emissions. "Batfish" also detected her on radar at a range of bearing 336 degrees from "Batfish". At 04:12, "Batfish" submerged to radar depth along "Ro-113"′s track with "Ro-113" yards away and closing. At 04:48, "Batfish" fired three torpedoes from her <a href="stern">stern</a> <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s for a run to their target. At 04:49, the first torpedo hit "Ro-113", creating a large yellow fireball and blowing her apart. "Ro-113" sank with all hands at , going under so quickly that "Batfish"′s second and third torpedoes missed.
On 20 February 1945, the Imperial Japanese Navy declared "Ro-113" to be presumed lost in the Luzon Strait with all 59 men on board. The Japanese struck her from the Navy list on 10 May 1945.
